message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest nephrotic syndrome, which can be caused by various renal diseases. Option (A) corresponds to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which is frequently seen in patients with obesity-related glomerulopathy, and is consistent with the patient’s BMI. Option (B) corresponds to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and option (C) corresponds to membranous nephropathy, both of which are less likely based on the patient’s lab results. Option (D) corresponds to amyloidosis, which is less likely given the absence of other suggestive findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest nephrotic syndrome, and the most likely diagnosis is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which can be seen under light microscopy as segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli. Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Diffuse thickening of glomerular capillaries is seen in membranous glomerulopathy. Amyloid deposition in the mesangium is seen in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with periorbital and bilateral lower extremity edema, as well as proteinuria and fatty casts in the urine. These suggest nephrotic syndrome. The most likely finding in a renal biopsy of a patient with nephrotic syndrome is segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli. Fibrin crescents and amyloid deposition are more commonly seen in other types of glomerulonephritis, while diffuse thickening of glomerular capillaries is seen in diabetic nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, and the urine sample shows proteinuria, hematuria, and fatty casts. Segmental sclerosis of glomeruli is the most likely finding under light microscopy in a patient with nephrotic syndrome. Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space suggest rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Amyloid deposition in the mesangium is seen in patients with amyloidosis. Diffuse thickening of glomerular capillaries suggests membranous nephropathy.

A renal biopsy is ordered to determine the cause of the nephrotic syndrome. Under light microscopy, segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli is more commonly associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which is a likely diagnosis in this case. Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, diffuse thickening of glomerular capillaries may be seen in diabetic nephropathy, and amyloid deposition in the mesangium may be seen in amyloidosis.

Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, diffuse thickening of glomerular capillaries is seen in diabetic nephropathy, and amyloid deposition in the mesangium is seen in amyloidosis.
